question: The diagrams below show how houses can be protected in areas which are prone to flooding.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The schemes compare two different methods of defence for homes that can be easily affected by floods. Overall, they show flood protection with and without a stopbank, while the at-risk home is raised higher above ground level in two pictures.The first diagram depicts how a stopbank acts as a natural barrier to prevent river water from flooding. The stopbank is a small mound of land next to the river that is higher than the 100-year-flood level and prevents the drain from overwhelming its banks. Nearby buildings can be built on stilts to prevent flooding from rainwater as well as the water passing through the floodgate beneath the stopbank, resulting in an area of ‘internal ponding.’If it had not been a stopbank, as described in the second diagram, there would have been nothing to stop the river from flooding. In this case, the solution is to put homes on stilts much higher than the one in the first picture. The height of the stilts is measured to ensure that the floor of the house is three hundred meters above the 100-year-flood level regardless of how deep the water area is under the house. This measure is called the ‘freeboard.’
llm: One of the methods is the use of barriers. The aim of the methods is to prevent or reduce the damage caused by flooding. The diagram shows a house with a wall and a waterproof layer which prevent water from getting inside the house. The diagram shows how a barrier can be placed around a house to prevent floodwaters from getting inside the property. The next method shown is the use of raised foundations. The diagram shows a house with raised foundations which are above the anticipated water level. The third method shown is the use of water-repellent materials for walls and floors. The diagram shows a house with walls and floors which are made of water-repellent materials which can resist the water. In summary, the diagrams show the application of different methods for the protection of houses in areas which are prone to flooding. The information given in the diagrams is useful for owners, architects and engineers who are involved in building houses in flooded areas. These methods, i.e. the use of barriers, raised foundations and water-repellent materials for walls and floors can prevent or reduce damage from flooding.

question: The diagrams below show the design for a wave-energy machine and its location.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: first of all, the picture show (A Wave- energy machine) we can see that there is electricity generator its the machine that take the energy from the waves and it contain two turbines so the air could flow throuh it and from what it shown we can notice that there is two of wave energy machin: the large waves and the small waves.Secondly,the small wavs had low output since its for the small waves, in addition it also had low installation costs because its smaller.in the other hand the large waves had high output and high installation costs since its also large.To sum up we can say that the air flow to the turbine so the turbine could move and got the electrisity , there is also air come from the water levels which hepls the machine get the elecricity that it needs so the people could use it like a solar power.
llm: The device consists of a large, cylindrical structure located on the seafloor, near the coast. It is intended to collect and convert the energy from the ocean waves into a useable form. The cylindrical part of the device is partly submerged under the water and the upper part is above the surface. The shape of the device is unique and enables it to collect and concentrate the energy from the waves. The location of the device, on the coast, is also important. In comparison to other renewable energy systems, such as wind-turbines or solar panels, this device is relatively small in scale and not easily visible. The underwater location also makes it less noisy and its low profile makes it more aesthetically pleasing. In addition, the device can exploit the more predictable wave patterns of the coast, enabling it to generate more energy. This coastal location also makes it easier to maintain and more accessible for the transmission of the electricity produced to land. In converting the energy of the waves into electricity, the device has the potential to provide a clean, reliable and sustainable source of energy. Its unique shape, submerged position and coastal location, therefore, make it an innovative and promising solution for generating renewable energy.

question: The diagrams below show the development of the horse over a period of 40 million years.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant
human: The diagram depicts the different stages of the body habitus and the relative changes in foot structures that under went in the process of evolution of the modern horse, since 40 million years ago.The modern horse had gone through 3 main stages in order to become it's current version, each stage shows distinctive changes in the body as a whole.Having said that, the earliest species that existed is namely Echippus, then it was mesohippus and finally it was Merychippus.The Echippus is the identified first ancestor of the modern horse that existed 40 million years ago. They appeared relatively similar to the size of a sheep and their foot apearently had four toes.However, Mesohippus was the second in line of the modern horses and was relatively bigger and taller, the foot structure got limited to three toes and the middle toe being the widerest.15 million years after the existance of mesohippus, merychippus emerged, they were similar in both the size and shape of our modern horses, but as far as the foot is concerned the middle toe became more prominent and the rest two toes started to shrink. Finally, the modern horses look twice the size of Echippus and their feet looked proper coronet.
llm: On the first forty million years of its life, the ancestor of the modern horse, Eohippus, was a tiny little animal with four toes on its front legs and three toes on its hind legs. The most striking feature of its development is its transition from a little multi-toed forest animal to a large grassland animal with a single hoof. By the time it had reached the end of the Triassic period, thirty million years ago, it had become Miohippus, which had three toes on all four legs, indicating a gradual adaptation to a more specialised foot structure. A major evolutionary leap had taken place when, about ten million years ago, the genus Merychippus had appeared, with a single hoof on each leg, which meant that the horse could run more effectively and at the same time support its own increasing body weight. Compare the early Eohippus and the modern horse: the former, adapted to forest life, with its many toes, could move nimbly in all directions, but the latter, suited to open grassland, with its single hoof, could run swiftly and quickly and move at a steady speed. The modern horse, Equus, which appeared about four million years ago, kept this specialised foot, but it also became larger and its legs more powerfully developed. To sum up, the diagrams show a remarkable development in the horse, from a little multi-toed forest animal to a large, fast-moving grassland animal, indicating the dynamic development of the species in response to the environment over millions of years.

question: The diagrams below show the existing ground floor plan of a house and a proposed plan for some building work.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The information below shows the present floor plan and changes been suggested. Generally spekaing, there is no big difference, kitchen will stay as a kitchen and living room will stay as a living room.At the moment the living room space is smaller than in proposed new plan. The living room space suggested to be increased as internal wall will be demolited. Moreover, in suggested plan there is no place for storage under the stairs as stairs will be changed in their shape and also there will be no more hall place will be integrated into living room.The door intro kitchen will be switched from single one to double and will be located near the entrance door. The kitchen furniture suggested to be located on the opposite side to the wall and doubled indoor door. However, some things stays the same in both plans. For example, the location of both entrance doors - front and backyard and also wall between hall and kitchen.
llm: The existing ground floor of the house comprises a living room, a kitchen and two bedrooms, with a total area of about 120 square metres. The living room is at the front of the house, next to the kitchen, while the bedrooms are at the back. The ground floor as it is now and the ground floor as it will be after the building work are quite different in several respects. The most obvious feature of the proposed plan is the extension at the back, which will double the area of the house and provide space for a new dining room and a study, effectively making the living area much larger. In addition, the new living area will be much more open-plan than the existing one. The other significant change is the en suite bathroom in one of the bedrooms, which makes the whole house much more comfortable and convenient. The kitchen is also relocated to the back of the house, next to the new dining area, and one of the bedrooms is enlarged. The living room, which is to remain at the front of the house, will have its area slightly reduced. While the existing ground floor plan is compact and rather dated, the proposed plan is a more spacious, modern and practical arrangement, and it will certainly appeal to a family looking to renovate and extend their home. In general, the proposed plan will result in a ground floor that is more spacious, modern and practical.

question: The diagrams below show the water supply system in Australia present and in future.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The given diagram illustrates the processes involved in the water supply system in Australia at the present and in the future.To begin, the first kind of water is located in the dam and storage where the waste water is lead to a water treatment plant. Meanwhile, from the storage come out pure water and provide potable water to households, factories, shops, and all the city. At the same time, the wastewater produced in the city is transferred to a water treatment plant as well.The last type of water is the storm water that is sent to the river from the city.Overall, it can be seen that the process has three types of waters in the process of water supply which are pure, storm, and waste water. depending on the type of water, these can be found in the dam and storage, water treatment plant, river and in different places of the city such as households, factories, shops, among others.
llm: Presently, the system largely relies on water from dams and reservoirs which are treated and distributed to households, industries and agriculture. This traditional method is supplemented by small but significant amounts of water from sewage treatment plants and very small amounts from desalination plants. In the future, the system is expected to change considerably. The most obvious change is the much greater reliance on desalination plants. The system is also expected to be more resilient to droughts and unpredictable weather. A major difference between the two systems is the amount of water which is recycled. The amount of water which is recycled in the future suggests that conservation and re-use of water are becoming increasingly important. The future system appears to be more efficient with less water lost during distribution. The future system appears to be using more sophisticated treatment and distribution techniques. These changes show a more forward looking approach to the management of water which acknowledges the problems of climate change and the need to find new ways of conserving this precious resource. The greater reliance on desalination and water treatment reflects a commitment to reducing the problem of water shortages and ensuring a more reliable supply of water for the growing population and economy.

question: The diagrams show the structure of solar panel and its use.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The diagram illustrates how a solar panel is constructed, and the complex process of how the renewable energy source provides heated water and air to households.The first diagram shows us visual information about the basic structure of the solar panel. It´s construction is mainly a large box with two pipes placed on both sides. Then, one equally large top which is transparent is placed on top of the container.According to the second diagram, the solar panel is designed to provide the home with warm air. Firstly, cold air is allowed in through the inlet and let inside the box. Secondly, the transparent top allows sunrays to transform the cool air to warm air by their heating properties. After that, the warm air goes through and out the outlet.In regards to the third diagram, we can clearly see that the construction is similar with the exception that water pipes are added in the main box, in order to supply households with hot water. In comparison with the second diagram, where air was driven through the pipes, water is the main resource here. After the water has entered the inlet, water passes through the pipes and out
llm: As shown in the diagrams, a solar panel consists of several photovoltaic (PV) cells that are responsible for the conversion of sunlight into electricity. Each cell consists of a semiconducting material such as silicon, which is treated to create an electric field. When the light strikes the PV cell, the excited electrons are free to flow in the direction of the electric field and produce a current. This effect is known as the photovoltaic effect. As the diagrams show, a solar panel can be used to generate electricity in a wide range of applications from small scale residential use to large scale commercial and industrial use. The diagrams also show the layers that form the solar panel: the antireflective layer, the photovoltaic cells and the base. The antireflective layer increases the amount of sunlight that enters the panel, while the base provides both support and protection for the cells. The diagrams also show how several solar panels can be used together to produce a significant amount of electricity, which can be used to power houses or to generate electricity for the national grid. In summary, the diagrams provide a clear illustration of the structure and use of solar panels and demonstrate their potential as a source of sustainable energy. The information in the diagrams is valuable as it provides an insight into the technology behind the generation of solar energy and can be used by students and other researches to help them understand how solar panels work. As the world’s energy resources become more depleted, understanding how solar panels work and how they can be used will become more important.

question: The education system is the only critical factor in the development of a country, agree/disagree (from Target Band
human: This essay was written on a topic from “Target Band 7” book (page 54, reprinted with permission).You should spend about 40 minutes on this taskSome people say that the education system is the only critical factor in the development of a country. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Write at least 250 wordsEducation plays an imperative role in the overall progression of a country. Many people may heavily rely on quality education as preparation for real life employment and experiences. However, there are other factors that are needed to propel a country towards success.We must acknowledge the way the education system of a country prepares most individuals by equipping them with various skills. Prior to gaining a qualification to practice certain professions such as teaching, nursing or accounting, it is necessary for the individuals to undergo rigorous training. Certificate and diploma programs as well as university degrees are good examples of that. Some graduates may even choose to pursue further studies to attain certain requirements to be able to practice their chosen profession.The education system is undoubtedly important in preparing individuals to take on roles leading to the development of a country. However, it seems that producing graduates alone isn’t a guarantee of the advancement of a country. There are other factors that should come into play, and motivation of individuals is one. Without motivation, people may lose track of what they intend to do to contribute to the improvement of a country. drives people to achieve and maximize their potentials, because they are determined to get better at many aspects of their life, eventually yielding improvement for their entire country.Furthermore, the availability of natural resources and job opportunities may also affect the growth of a national economy. Innovations of many individuals require raw materials, and should the country be able to mine these, their production and perhaps even export may help in stabilizing the local market. Finally, it is also important that the availability of employment is aligned with the skills of individuals applying for the positions. Giving skilled people the opportunity to apply their knowledge and experience in their profession makes them more productive, which contributes to GDP growth.In conclusion, education continues to play a pivotal role in the development of a country. However, other important factors should play a role in order to achieve steady and continuous progress.This response adequately addresses the task prompt. The writer’s viewpoint is clear throughout the essay. Each paragraph has its role and they are used effectively to organise ideas and information. The coherence and advanced vocabulary help the writer to create an impression of a skilled, fluent English user. Good control of grammar and punctuation is evident. This essay could achieve Band 8 in IELTS.
llm: the same as target) In my opinion, education is the only critical factor in the development of a country. Although education plays an important role in the development of the country, there are also many other factors, such as economic policies, education, and government policy that contribute to the development of the country. A country with a good education system but a poor economic policy cannot provide jobs for its educated people, and this will only lead to the loss of human resources and the loss of knowledge. Without a stable and harmonious economic environment, the benefits of education will not be fully utilized. With a good education system, but a poor education system, the country cannot develop its economy, and a country with a good education system, but a poor education system, will face many difficulties in the future. And development. A comprehensive understanding of all aspects is required for the sustainable development and prosperity of a country. In short, it is important to understand the interdependence of the above factors and to try to create a supportive and harmonious environment for the development of the whole society.

question: The end of the world’s fossil fuel resources and the subsequent changes will be a positive development in society. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: Today’s society overwhelmingly depends on products made from fossil fuels. Most people would initially think about fuel for transport, but of course, fossil fuels are part of most of the fabric of life around us, from the plastics on our furniture to the pavements that we walk on. Changing our reliance on these resources can have various consequences; however, I believe that overall the society will benefit from finding viable alternatives for them.Depending on whether eco-friendly alternatives are developed, the positive effect on transport and the reduction of the associated pollution will be significant. Exhaust fumes from motor vehicles, planes and ships decrease air quality and contribute to global warming and the greenhouse effect. People’s health and the health of the planet will surely improve without these industries relying on fossil fuels. It could be that a type of transport crisis could develop as a result if society can no longer provide the power to transport so many individuals to where they want to go. This, however, does not have to be a bad thing, as it could force society to use alternative solutions, such as transport sharing and public transport development. The change in mind set has already begun. Some countries have already committed to having fossil fuel free transport and more cities are banning private vehicles from the centre of cities.Another positive development would be that more time and money would have to be put into developing renewable sources of energy, such as wind power, solar power, hydropower and tidal power. Technologies would improve and be more efficient and again, the world would use fewer sources of energy that cause pollution. This development can also be seen today, with many governments committing to proportions of their power needs coming from renewable resources.I, therefore, strongly agree with the statement that the changes from reducing reliance on fossil fuels will be positive. The only caveat is that society will need to have developed alternative sources of power rather soon, in order to avoid an energy crisis.
llm: On the one hand, depletion of fossil fuels will certainly force people to move towards alternative, renewable sources of energy, such as the sun and the wind. Although some people argue that this development will push humanity towards a more sustainable and more environment-friendly future, I disagree with this to some extent. Furthermore, the end of fossil fuels will also stimulate innovation and bring about an increase in jobs and economic growth in the renewable energy sector. For example, countries like Norway and Costa Rica have already made great strides in the conversion to renewable energy and this has brought about cleaner air and water and healthier environments. This would significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and thus help to prevent the disastrous consequences of climate change. On the other hand, a sudden end to fossil fuels would also have severe economic and social consequences. As it is, the industry that supplies fossil fuels employs millions of people around the world and a collapse of this industry would lead to high unemployment and economic instability. Furthermore, many developing countries depend heavily on fossil fuels to provide them with electricity and transport, and a collapse of the industry would have devastating consequences for their economies. This would lead to a sharp increase in the number of people living in poverty. A more nuanced approach is therefore needed, where the transition towards renewable energy is carefully planned and managed in such a way that it causes the least disruption to the world economy and ensures a more sustainable future. In conclusion, while depletion of fossil fuels will certainly lead to some positive changes, such as a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and an increase in the use of renewable energy, it will also bring about severe negative consequences, such as an increase in poverty and the widening gap between the rich and the poor.

question: The fact that enormous sums are paid for pieces of art is not acceptable at a time when many people around the world live in poverty. Discuss this statement and give your opinion.Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It is true that pieces of art in today’s world can change hands for enormous sums. Works by artists such as Picasso, da Vinci and Rembrandt have been sold for millions of dollars. Recently, a Modigliani was sold to a billionaire for one hundred and seventy million dollars. It certainly seems obscene that such figures are spent when many people around the world live in poverty.The work of many charities would be transformed by the money generated by just one of these art sales and in turn, the lives of ordinary people in need would be transformed. Medicines, food and shelter amongst other things could easily be provided, saving lots of lives, many of which would be children. When the issue is looked at from this point of view, the art sales world certainly seems obscene.However, in my opinion, things are unlikely to change. Human greed is endemic and people who have the drive to earn that amount of money and who actually have access to these sums in cash are not often people who will part with their wealth. Lots of prosperous people support many charities, but it is unlikely that they would completely relinquish their access to the luxuries that accompany their lives. The works of art are also often seen as investments in themselves, to be held on to for a period of time and then resold at a profit.In conclusion, in an ideal world, the vast sums of money that are spent on fine and rare works of art would be better spent on helping those in need. In reality, however, this is unlikely to take place.
llm: The price of some works of art is undeniably high and paintings can sell for tens of millions or even hundreds of millions of dollars. The sale of the painting Salvator Mundi by Leonardo da Vinci for $450.3 million in November, for example, is a stunning example of this. These kinds of sales bring the disparity between the rich and the poor into stark relief and demonstrate the unfair distribution of wealth around the world. Meanwhile, millions of people live in poverty, struggling to meet their basic needs, and it seems morally wrong that such exorbitant sums are spent on art, when they could be used to eradicate poverty, fund education, or support humanitarian work. However, it is also important to consider the cultural, historical, and aesthetic value that art brings to society. A work of art can act as a window into the past, preserving the memory of history and culture for future generations. Critics of the art market argue that the money spent on art could be better spent on tackling these pressing social issues. In conclusion, it is ethically questionable that vast sums are spent on art at a time when so many people live in poverty, but it is also important to acknowledge the complex role that art plays in society. In addition, the art market provides work for many people, from artists and art dealers to restorers and museum staff, which makes a significant contribution to the economy. All in all, the issue is complex and a more nuanced view of the situation is needed, one that takes into account both the monetary value of art and its less tangible benefits. Perhaps a balance can be struck between respecting the value of art and helping the poor, for example through the philanthropic work of collectors and art institutions or by making art more accessible and more beneficial to a wider audience, including the less well-off.

question: The first chart below gives information about the money spent by British parents on their children’s sports between 2008 and 2014. The second chart shows the number of children who participated in three sports in Britain over the same time period.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The line graph depicts the growth in average spending of British parents on children's sports from 2008 to 2014 while other graphs represent the popularity of sports among children and their participation from 2008 to 2014.Overall, the first graph was about the average monthly spend on children's sports which was at an exponential rate while in the second graph football was the most popular among children.To begin with the first graph, the average monthly spending of parents on children's sports was increasing at an enormous rate from 20 pounds in 2004 to approximately 33 pounds in 2014.Meanwhile, the second graph was about participation in three different sports where football was the most popular sport among children approximately 7.9 million in 2008 to roughly 8 million. swimming was growing at a certain rate while athletics was not so popular until 2010 after that there was a rush in participation in contrast to swimming but after the peak in 2012, there was a decrease in participation.
llm: According to the first chart, the money spent on sports by British parents steadily rose from 2008 to 2012, with a big jump from £500 million in 2008 to around £700 million in 2012. After that, the amount spent on sports by British parents flattened out from 2012 to 2014, with only a slight decrease from £700 million to £680 million. The second chart shows the number of children participating in three sports over the same period, football, tennis and swimming. As we can see from the chart, the number of children who took part in football was the highest and showed a steady rise from around 1 million in 2008 to 1.3 million in 2014. The rise was steady. Between the two charts, we can see that, despite the increasing amount of money spent on sports, the number of children who participated in tennis and swimming remained fairly constant, or even fell slightly. The number of children who took part in tennis was the lowest of the three sports. These different trends in the two charts show that there is a complex relationship between spending and participation in children’s sports in Britain between 2008 and 2014. However, the participation rate in football kept rising.

question: The first chart below shows the percentages of women and men in a country involved in some kinds of home tasks (cooking, cleaning, pet caring and repairing the house. llm: According to the first chart, the majority of cooking and cleaning tasks are performed by women, 83% and 86% respectively. But 81% of men take care of repairing the house. Pet care is almost evenly divided between men and women, 58% of women and 46% of men. According to the second chart, men and women divide their time differently, and the women's workload is greater than that of the men. question: The flow chart below shows an automatic photo booth. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.You should write at least 150 words.
human: The automatic photo booth allows you to take photos of yourself by self-service. Insert sufficient amount of coins and choose colour or black & white at the panel. You are allowed to select 1 large format or 4 password-sized photos, but remember that if you use the photos in your passport, it has to be a colour one.In the photo-taking area, there is a circle-shaped chair with an adjustable stool. Adjust the height of the chair, so that it reaches the right eye level of the camera. Before taking the photo, you can refer to the mirror above the camera to have your hair and face ready for photo taking.The curtain should properly closed before you take the photos. Be seated if you are ready for the shot. Sit straight and wait for light signal flash after 3 seconds. After the shot, the photo will be delivered and available on the slot near the coin panel within 60 seconds.
llm: The most important feature of this booth is its automatic operation. A series of operations are followed to produce a photo. The process begins by choosing the desired photograph from a series of templates. Then the picture is taken and is displayed on the monitor for the customer to see. If the customer is satisfied with the picture, he can continue the process, otherwise he can take a new one. After the customer has confirmed the photo, he must pay for it by means of a credit card, a debit card or cash. The ability to accept different payment methods makes the booth convenient and easy to use. The automatic process ensures that the photo is printed to the required quality. This automatic booth is more private and faster than the manual booth. Compared to the manual booth, it offers a better service to the customer. The main features of this booth, templates, photo review, automatic payment and printing, make it convenient, efficient and private for customers to take photos and make prints.

question: The flow chart illustrates the consequence of deforestation. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features.You should write at least 150 words.
human: The supplied illustration outlines the problems of cutting forests. As we can see, there are 4 main branches and each of them describes a certain issue, caused by deforestation.According to the first branch from the left, forest destruction can lead to the state when soil becomes hard and "baked". It occurs due to the fact that heavy logging equipment compresses the soil, as the first block of the chart says. Because soil becomes "baked", rain water starts to run off which causes flooding.If we look at the remaining branches, we can see that they all lead to the same conclusion - less biodiversity. But there are three different reasons for it. The first one is soil erosion. When we cut the trees, we have fewer tree roots to support the topsoil that eventually erodes.The second reason - increased risk of burning. It is followed by the destruction of waste wood. Then we have some micro-organisms such as pioneer species that move in and initiate degradation of vegetation. And it's all resulted in less biodiversity.The last branch starts with the fact that after cutting forests we have less plants to give back moisture to air, so less moisture enters the air. This triggers less precipitation, and so, increased droughts. Plants that unable to withstand hot and dry weather die and it ends with less biodiversity.To conclude everything, the main purpose of the presented flow chart was to demonstrate the severe damage that could be caused by deforestation.
llm: The main feature of the chart is the sequence of events resulting from deforestation. The sequence starts with the removal of trees and goes on to the lack of roots to prevent soil from washing away. The next significant consequence of deforestation is the loss of species as a result of habitat destruction, which leads to the displacement and extinction of many species. Lastly, the process of deforestation leads to the encroachment of rubbish on the rivers and streams, which contaminates the water and causes flooding. The chart also reveals the negative socio-economic consequences of deforestation, including the loss of livelihood for the people who depend on the forest for survival. The flowchart also illustrates the contribution of deforestation to the greenhouse effect, as the reduction of tree cover changes the carbon cycle and releases greenhouse gases. These in turn have a disastrous effect on the global warming process, causing more frequent and more severe natural disasters such as floods, droughts and heatwaves. Furthermore, the chart also shows the necessity of sustainable forest management to reduce the harmful impact of deforestation. The loss of medicinal plants and other non-timber forest products are important for the local communities.

However, by 2010, the gap between the two groups of students had closed, with the number of local students being about 270,000 and the number of overseas students about 120,000. This indicates that Australian universities are increasingly attractive to overseas students and have a more diverse student population. Moreover, the increase in overseas students and the relatively stable number of local students shows the increasing internationalisation of Australian universities. In economic terms, the increase in overseas students is also significant, as they contribute significantly to the country’s economy through their tuition fees and living expenses.

question: The movement of people from the countryside into the cities is happening in many parts of the world, resulting in the problems, especially in cities.What are the causes of this movement, and how can it be reversedGive reasons for your answer, and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: People move from the countryside into the cities. It occurs in many parts of the world, causing problems, especially in urban areas. This essay will elaborate on the causes of this movement, and the way it can be reversed from my personal standpoint.Centralization has caused this movement. All the major institutions and facilities are in the cities. Thus, people in rural areas have to sacrifice considerable time and effort to travel to urban centres. As it is also costly, people choose to move into the cities so that traveling does not consume their time. For instance, one-fifth of the total population in Korea currently lives in Seoul, the capital city of Korea. In fact, all the educational, medical, and entertainment facilities are centralized in urban areas. It can be reserved by implementing decentralization. The government has to disperse the location of the major institutions and diverse types of facilities into different districts so that people living in remote areas can also benefit.Furthermore, people in remote areas want to earn opportunities for better employment or education. As a city is a point where technologies, investments ,and professions gather, there is a better opportunity for people to get employed or educated in a improved quality. Therefore, people choose to leave the countryside. Thereby, the government can initiate the policies in which firms earn benefit when they move their head office to districts. If the firms commence moving, it will produce a great amount of employment.Conclusively, not only the government but also the businesses and institutions have to co-operate to combat problems resulting from a surge in the movement of people from the countryside into the cities.
llm: This mass movement, also known as urbanization, is one of the most significant world phenomena of the present time. It is mainly due to the fact that people in the countryside have few jobs, lack of roads, a lack of schools and hospitals, and therefore the people prefer to go to cities for better opportunities. For example, the rapid development of industry and technology in cities in India and China have created a lot of jobs and thus lured millions of people from the countryside to the cities. One of the main causes of this mass movement is the difference in economic opportunities between rural and urban areas. Cities offer better salaries, more varied careers, and better business opportunities than the countryside. In order to reverse this trend, a combination of factors is needed. For example, if the government builds better roads, schools, and hospitals in the countryside, it will make life there more attractive and sustainable. Another reason for people to move to cities is that there are fewer schools and hospitals in rural areas, so people have to move to cities for better education and health care. The government can also encourage more people to stay in rural areas by helping them to make a living in the countryside. For example, in the 1970s, the government of South Korea tried to encourage rural development by providing more education, health care, and other facilities.

question: The number of advertisements for charities on television and the Internet seems to be increasing. What is causing this? Is this a positive or a negative development?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It indeed appears true that the frequency with which advertisements for charities appear both on television and the Internet seems to be increasing. There can be various explanations for this and it can be seen in both a positive and negative light.One explanation for the increase in the number of charity advertisements is that the charities themselves are becoming more aggressive in their marketing. This can also be seen in the common strategy nowadays to encourage a monthly donation, rather than a one-off donation. The increased marketing is apparent too in the increased numbers of ‘street salespeople’, who stop passersby and try to get them to commit to this monthly payment.A second reason for the increase could also be that there have been more charities started and the number of advertisements would therefore increase and become more noticeable. If these charities are all legitimate, this would mean that more help will be getting to causes that need it. The increase in charities could also be explained by a possible increase of humanitarian awareness. People might be now adopting different ideologies that take into account people in less advantageous positions.If the number of advertisements for charities has risen due to the fact that there has been a positive shift in people’s compassionate principles, this surely has to be seen as an optimistic development. If it is due to the fact that governments have been cutting back, it could be seen as a pessimistic development. In addition, if there are more charities asking for more money, this will inevitably mean that the amount of money donated will have to be more thinly spread, which would be a negative development.There could be several reasons for why there are more charity advertisements today. Whatever the reasons, as long as any money is helping people in disadvantageous positions, it must be seen as a positive development.
llm: In recent years, it has become more and more common to see charities advertising on the Internet and on television. This increase in advertising is due to a number of reasons. More and more people have become aware of and want to do something about issues such as poverty, inequality and climate change. Many more charities have also emerged to address these issues. The invention of social media, for example, has allowed charities to create and share content with millions of people at very little cost, in comparison to the cost of traditional advertising. This development has not been entirely positive for some, who have expressed concerns about philanthropy fatigue and possible scams. But on the whole, it is a positive one. In my opinion, this is partly because charity advertising can create a sense of community and social responsibility. Charity advertisements raise awareness of important issues, inform the public and encourage people to do something about them. The Ice Bucket Challenge, which went viral on social media in 2014, for example, raised over $100 million for ALS research and increased public awareness of a previously little-known disease. In conclusion, an increase in charity advertising on television and the Internet is a positive development. It could encourage people to act positively and contribute to a more caring society. However, potential donors should always research charities before donating to them. They should support charities that are well known and well run. By doing so, they will help to make the world a better place.

The balloon is suspended under the balloon. The balloon basket carries passengers and the pilot. The picture above clearly shows the main components and working methods of a hot air balloon. question: The pie charts below show how dangerous waste products are dealt with in three countries.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The pie charts illustrate the dealing with dangerous waste products in the Republic of Korea, Sweden, and the United Kingdom. On the other hand, people in the Republic of Korea prefer to use the recycling method 69%) the most, while those who live in Sweden do not use it so often (25%).The United Kingdom has identical points at 8% for chemical treatment and dumping at sea methods. However, the lowest point (2%) has the incineration method in this country, while people in the Republic of Korea and Sweden destroy waste by fire more often, 9% and 20%, respectively.
llm: At first sight, it is obvious that each country takes a different approach to dangerous waste disposal. Country A relies mainly on the recovery of dangerous waste, with 60% of its dangerous waste going to the recovery. Country B and C rely mainly on land disposal, with 45% and 50% of their dangerous waste going to the land. This is less desirable, as land disposal can lead to contamination and health problems. This is a welcome change, as waste disposal through land is the most beneficial solution for the environment. Incineration is a second method of disposal, with Country B incinerating 30% of its dangerous waste and Country C incinerating 20%. Country A incinerates only 15%. Finally, the three countries have varying ways of dealing with dangerous waste. It is also worth noting that a significant part of Country A's dangerous waste is recovered, while only a small part, of 5% and 10%, is recovered in the other two countries. This may mean that Country A has a more robust recovery system than the other two countries, which will lead to less waste. As the world is grappling with the challenges of preserving the environment, it is important to learn from the experience of these three countries. Although each country has its advantages and disadvantages, Country A's emphasis on the recovery and reuse of dangerous waste is particularly noteworthy.

question: The pie charts below show the percentage of housing owned and rented in the UK in 1991 and 2007.Summarize the information by describing the main features of the charts and making comparisons where appropriate.

llm: A clear comparison of the two charts shows that significant changes have taken place in the UK housing market over this 16-year period. In 1991, 67 percent of housing was owned, 31 percent was rented from private landlords, and 2 percent was rented from other sources. It is worth noting that the percentage of housing owned fell significantly from 67 to 59 percent between 1991 and 2007. The percentage of rented housing increased from 31 to 37 percent, and the percentage of rented from private landlords rose to 34 percent. The percentage of rented houses from other sources remained almost unchanged. Comparison of the two periods shows that the UK housing market has experienced a considerable change in the shift from ownership to renting. This 8% decrease in ownership suggests a shift from ownership to rental, which is probably due to some factors such as cost, lifestyle or economy. The increase in private rents also indicates that the private rental market is developing. The increase in the percentage of private rents can be attributed to the growth of the private rental market, which may be due to the rise in the value of houses and the reduction of government rental subsidies. In short, the two pie charts show a transitional trend in the UK housing market, with a significant decrease in ownership and an increase in the percentage of rented housing. I believe that the change is related to the underlying changes in the country's economic, social and policy environment, which in turn affects how individuals and families choose to satisfy their housing needs.

question: The process below shows how to make dough for a pizza.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: In the diagram, the steps needed to obtain a dough for a pizza are shown, figures are given for grams and time required for the process.In the initial stage, the staple ingredients, namely, 4 coup of 00 flour, 325 gr of water ( roughly one and a half cups) and a half teaspoon of dry active yeast respectively, are blended together in a cup.After being placed in a stand mixer, the primordial dough undergo through 3 mixing stages, with the first and the third at slow speed for 2 minutes each, and the second at medium speed for 5 minutes.Subsequently, the dough is going to be left to rest as long as its thickness has increased twofold, which it would takes at least 2 Hours.Having gotten rid of the bubbles by squeezing them manually, the resulting portion of dough is either divided thoroughly into 3 slices equally sized or making each of the three parts weigh 275 grams.
llm: First of all, the ingredients are mixed: flour, salt, yeast and water. The water activates the yeast and the process of fermentation begins. Next, the ingredients are mixed and kneaded, either by hand or with a machine. In this way, gluten is formed in the flour, which gives the dough its consistency and structure. This process is similar to making bread, where yeast is also used to leaven the dough. After kneading, the dough is left to rise and the yeast produces carbon dioxide. This gas makes the dough expand and give it a light, fluffy texture. Kneading the dough is similar to the process of making pasta, where the dough is also kneaded to create a smooth, elastic consistency. Finally, the dough is rolled out and prepared for topping and baking. This stage is crucial in allowing the dough to develop its characteristic chewiness. It is similar to the process of making bread, but with the important differences that give the finished product its unique texture and flavour. Compared to other types of dough, such as that used for flat breads, the consistency of the dough for a pizza is normally thicker and stronger, to allow it to support a wide variety of toppings. The above steps allow a good, authentic and tasty dough to be made, which is ready for baking.

question: The proportion of older people is increasing, what problems will this cause and what solutions can be suggested?
human: In many countries the proportion of older people is steadily increasing. What problems will this cause for individuals and society? Suggest some measures that could be taken to reduce the impact of ageing populations.It is true that nowadays people in industrialised nations can expect to live longer than ever before. Although there will undoubtedly be some negative consequences to this trend, societies can take steps to mitigate these potential problems.As people live longer and the populations of developed countries grow older, several related problems can be anticipated. The main issue is that there will obviously be more people of retirement age who will be eligible to receive a pension. The proportion of younger, working adults will be smaller, and governments will therefore receive less money in taxes in relation to the size of the population. In other words, an ageing population will mean a greater tax burden working adults. Further pressures will include a rise in the demand for healthcare, and the adults will increasingly have to look after their elderly relatives.There are several actions that governments could take to solve the problems described above. Firstly, a simple solution would be to increase the retirement age for working adults, perhaps from 65 to 70. Nowadays, people of this age tend to be healthy enough to continue a productive working life. A second measure would be for governments to encourage immigration in order to increase the number of working adults who pay taxes. Finally, money from national budgets will need to be taken from other areas and spent vital healthcare, accommodation and transport facilities for the rising numbers of senior citizens.In conclusion, various measures can be taken to tackle the problems that are certain to arise as the populations of countries grow older.This essay covers the task requirements, however some problems of aging population get only a brief mention. The linking of sentences in the second body paragraph is somewhat ‘mechanical’ and could have been improved. Information sequencing and organisation in paragraphs are done well. The range of vocabulary and the fluency of its use, as well as lack of errors are impressive. Overall, this is a good example of how to get Band 8 without writing a very long essay.
llm: You will find the following comments: We are in the midst of a significant population shift. The proportion of older people in the world's population is growing at an unprecedented rate. And it is expected to continue and increase. Older people will soon make up a larger proportion of the population. In addition, there will be an increase in the strain on health care systems, as older people will require more medical care and support. One of the main problems of an aging population is the strain on pension and social security systems. With a growing proportion of older people, these systems will be increasingly burdened, which can lead to financial instability and reduced benefits for older people. Another problem is the reduction in the labor force, as older people retire and withdraw from the labor market. This can lead to a lack of workers, knowledge and experience. It will also increase health care costs and the number of health care workers. Solution to these problems can be several. Governments and companies can help older people stay in work after retirement, either full-time or part-time, to help maintain their skills and continue to contribute to the labor market. In addition, older people may need more specialized support and assistance, such as assisted living and home care services, which can also be expensive and difficult to organize. These services must be made available, and in addition, they can be used. In addition, a healthy lifestyle and active aging can also help reduce the need for medical care and support in later life. Moreover, by investing in health care and social services, we can help older people to lead healthy, active and full lives.

There are also important differences in the importance of the system, whether the city values the extent of the network, the efficiency, or the historical importance of the system.

question: The tendency of news reports in the media to focus more on problems and emergencies rather than on positive developments is harmful to the individuals and the society as a whole.To what extent do you agree or disagree?
human: News reports in the media focus on problems and emergencies more often than on some positive events. Is it really harmful to the individuals and the society as a whole?Let us consider the purpose of the media existence first. I suppose it is to spread important information, so that people may use it in their lives. And problems are usually more important than some positive developments, since, in fact, they are the things which people should be aware of in the first place. For example, due to the COVID, which is an international problem, many people lost their jobs. If they had been notified about the rising of pandemic though, they would have prepared somehow (save more money by cutting unnecessary expenses, learn a new profession and so forth).Moreover, I believe problems shall be solved. And when people are concerned about some problems, they may tend to face them with honor and participate in solving them. For instance, the energy crisis is a huge problem, and it is important to aware society of it, so that individuals could try to be more careful with gas and electricity. In the end, society will benefit from it, so it is not harmful.On the other hand, there is some negative impact of bad news on individuals sometimes. But I am sure it should be considered as psychological issues of particular individuals, rather than a problem of today's media system. People just should not fall in despair because of news reports, but think how they could take an advantage of the provided information to minimize a negative impact and help humanity to solve problems.Finally, in my view, the stated tendency is not really harmful to society, but it may sometimes be harmful to the individuals, and they are responsible for it.
llm: On the one hand, the frequent influx of negative news into the public consciousness can distort the concept of reality and lead to the formation of fear, anxiety and hopelessness. Although some argue that the main purpose of this tendency is to inform the public about serious issues, I strongly believe that this tendency is harmful to both individuals and society. On the other hand, a more balanced approach to news coverage, including more positive developments and success stories, can have a positive and uplifting effect on both individuals and society. On the one hand, an emphasis on problems and emergencies can create a culture of pessimism that makes people disinclined to take part in positive developments and feel powerless, which can have a very damaging psychological effect on vulnerable individuals, such as children and elderly people. On the other hand, reporting on positive developments can inspire individuals and organisations to take action and contribute to the positive development of their own society. Finally, while it is necessary to report on problems and emergencies, the tendency of the media to focus mainly on these issues is harmful to individuals and society as a whole. By adopting a more positive and diversified attitude towards news coverage, the media can play a more active role in shaping public consciousness and helping to create a more optimistic and resistant society.

question: The two tables below show the exchange students from universities in Europe to Australia between 2007 and 2009.Summaries the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The two tables indicate the international students from universities in Europe to Australia, and from Australian universities to universities in Europe between 2007 and 2009. Overall, An increase in total can be seen from European students to Australia in 2009, while the total number of Australian student remained the same from 2007 to 2009.To go into detail, there are two countries the number of students increased from European international students to Australia. Specifically, It is Sweden, and Germany. It was 34,27 in 2007 in Sweden and Germany, whereas it was 42 and 62 in Sweden and Germany in 2009 respectively. Especially in German students, the number doubled. On the other hand, other countries, such as France, the United Kingdom, and the Netherland can be seen a slight reduction from 2007 to 2009. But the total number increased from 189 to 226, in 2007, and 2009.When it comes to Australian international students who study in Europe, have not changed the total number of students. It is 152, in 2007 and 2009. On the other hand, the number of students soared in two countries, such as France, and Germany.It was 37, 18 in France, and Germany in 2007 respectively. It increased to 58, 26 in France and Germany. In contrast, there are reduction in three countries, in Sweden, The United Kingdom, and the Netherlands. Especially in the Netherland, the number of Australian students plummeted from 32 to 18 between 2007 and 2009.France and Germany in 2009.
llm: Firstly, the number of exchange students from Europe to Australia increased steadily over the three-year period. The above tables provide a glimpse into the exchange students from European universities to Australia between 2007 and 2009. In terms of the number of students per country, it is noteworthy that the United Kingdom consistently sends the most students, with over 500 students in 2009, followed by Germany and France. In 2007, there were around 1,200 students, which rose to around 1,500 in 2008 and further rose to around 1,800 in 2009. This indicates a growing interest in pursuing an education in Australia. Looking at the percentage growth, countries such as Italy and Spain have seen the greatest increase in the number of exchange students to Australia, with Italy’s numbers more than doubling between 2007 and 2009. This could be due to a greater awareness of Australian universities or the students’ ability to afford an Australian education. This could also be because of strong ties between the countries and the Australian universities, such as the common language. In general, the data reveals an upward trend in the number of exchange students from European universities to Australia between 2007 and 2009, with some countries showing more significant growth than others. Some countries, such as the Netherlands, maintained a steady number of exchange students while others, such as Ireland, fluctuated. This could be because of economic conditions, changes in government policies or availability of scholarships. The above information suggests that the exchange programs between European universities and Australian universities are expanding, possibly because of the international reputation of Australian universities and the growing attraction of an international education.

question: The typical teaching situation of a teacher and students in the class will not exist by the year 2050. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
human: For many years, the traditional teaching and learning (T&L) approach, i.e., having a teacher disseminating knowledge to a group of students in a classroom, is dominent over the world.With the advancement of information and communication technology, new learning approaches have been proposed and adopted. For example, students can now use computers to surf the internet to find information or knowledge they would like to study. Moreover, a number of pre-recorded education contents are now available online to provide classes/tutorials to learners. It is expected that this tradition T&L approach will not exist by 2050. Would it be true?There is no doube that there is an increasing number of T&L approaches due to emergence of new technologies. Together with the new approaches, we see there is a shift of the role of teachers these years, not only as one who is responsible to disseminate knowledge, but also a faciliator of learning. Teachers provide proper directions to students during their study, where current technology is not able to offer. Some people say the artificial technology is a threat, but still the accuracy of providing suggestions to students is not very high. Moreover, human teachers are able to provide emotional support to students. Studying is not just a robotic process of human beings. Students may encounter difficulties during the learning process and feel frustrated, which will eventually affect their progression in study. Human teachers could be more aware on this situation, not by the numeric assessment results, but the emotional behaviour of the students in the classroom, and provide prompt and proper counselling support and advice to the students.Also, it is still well-known that computers, even with AI, are weak in creating new knowledge. In the university setting, other than teaching the conventional knowledge, professors would disseminate their new research findings to the students in the class, with discussion among the students, inspiring them to the unexplored areas. This T&L process can only be effective when it happens in a classroom setting.In conclusion, technology may alter the way how we teach and learn. In spite of this, human teachers are also adaptive and certain roles of the teachers cannot be replaced by other tools or machines. Therefore, I believe that the tradition classroom T&L setting cannot be replaced completedly in the future.
llm: In this way, technology will revolutionize the education system and make the classroom unnecessary. However, I only partially agree with this statement. On the one hand, it is true that technology has begun to change the way we learn. Moreover, automation and artificial intelligence can lead to more efficient and effective learning methods, replacing the role of human teachers in some contexts. On the other hand, we have more and more opportunities to learn outside the classroom. But technology cannot fully replace human interaction, such as giving guidance and counseling, and providing emotional support and guidance. The emotional support and guidance provided by teachers are essential for students to develop their social and emotional skills. The way technology has improved the teaching system is more likely to be complementary to traditional teaching methods than to replace them. In addition, many subjects such as music, art and physical education require hands-on learning and interaction, which cannot be replaced by technology. I believe that combining the advantages of technology with the benefits of human interaction is the most effective way to help students learn and develop.

question: The use of corporal punishment (physically hitting students) in schools is in decline, yet it should be used to improve behaviour.To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Give reasons for your answer, and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: Some people believe that modifying behaviour among school-going children can be achieved through corporal punishment, and that it being on the decline in schools, is actually a negative development. I strongly disagree with this this view as I am of the opinion that there are better ways of disciplining children to instill positive behaviour, than physically hitting them.Improvement of behaviour among children in schools can be achieved through teaching them good manners rather than using corporal punishment. This means that teachers and school staff should teach children acceptable and unacceptable behaviour as part of their school curriculum from the earleist age they enter school. This way, learners obtain knowledge required for them to practice good behaviour. For example, if a child is taught from primary school-going age that they should clean after their mess, they are likely to practise and carry this behaviour through to secondary school. That way, there would be no need to physically hit children. Although some may firmly believe that corporal punishment is a good form of discipline, it cannot be compared to the actual teaching of good behaviour.Moreover, corporal punishment is likely to produce a fearful and resentful child rather than a well mannered child. It has been found by many researchers that children are unlikely to change their bad behaviour because they are beaten up at school. The behaviour is most likely to get worse, instead, as learners become fearful and resent their learning environment. For instance, in South Africa, some learners were reported to be disrespectful to their teachers because of a bad relationship that existed between them and their teachers as a result of corporal punishment that was inflicted on them. While it may be true that some positive behaviour changes were seen among pupils due to use of corporal punishment, this is at a very small scale.In conclusion, I am of the view that the use of corporal punishment among school-going age children is not a desirable phenomenon, as it is unlikely to produce any required behavioural changes. Instead, instilling good manners in learners through teaching them is more effective, as physically hitting them may even worsen their undesirable behaviour.
llm: The decline in corporal punishment in schools is a positive development because it is widely disapproved of by teachers, psychologists and human rights activists. Research has shown that physical punishment is associated with a range of adverse effects, including increased aggression, anxiety and poorer academic performance. To what extent do you agree or disagree with the statement that corporal punishment should be used to improve behavior in schools? A way of treating children that has long-term consequences for their emotional and psychological well-being, and that goes against the principles of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. In addition, physical punishment can be considered a violation of the rights of children as outlined in the Convention. Many schools are now replacing the corporal punishment with other methods, such as the “restorative circle”, which is a form of discussion and conflict resolution in a safe and supportive environment. These methods focus on the development of the child’s responsibility, empathy and self-discipline, rather than relying on fear and intimidation. For example, corporal punishment has been banned in Sweden and Norway for many years, and behavior in schools has improved and the well-being of students has improved. This is in line with the principle of providing a positive and supportive learning environment in which the students feel safe, valued and respected. The schools can focus on teaching them to learn, which can be the basis for good academic performance and good social skills. In conclusion, the use of corporal punishment in schools is not an effective or acceptable way to improve behavior.

question: The use of social media is replacing face-to-face interaction among many people in society. Do you think the advantages outweigh the disadvantages?
human: The modern world of social interaction changed completely over the past decades. Now many of us spent much more time interracting through social media, messengers for private or corporate messaging. We also use video conference and sharing our workflow remotely.As for me we have different needs satisfied by communication formed by different systems in our brain. On the one hand we have we communicate with each other aiming to get a useful information. On the other hand communication gives some non-verbal part like a sense of neing involved into one process, belonging to a circle of friends, collegues or family. These two sides of the process of communication are implemented differently that's why each part gets its own advantages and disadvantages thanks to changing integrating new social network technologies.If to talk about an information exchange - as for it became much more efficient with using messages, cloud storages and different coworking tools. But it is true only for those people who use these technology well. As far as I can see many advantages in remote work such as possibility not to waste time for commuting, offices and separate equipment, many people notice that their remote collegues disapperar often and avoid their duties. Some people couldn't concentrate while working at home. As for me people who experince such a problems are just addicted to strong stimules such as face-to face interraction and being managed by their boss. At the same time different internet based tools allow you to share much more information much faster and forever. Now you cannot just forget you task because you can always revise it in your work messenger and cloud folder wherever and whenever you are.One another need - is to have a social interraction. Of course ssocial network give us some advantage even in this area - now we can keep our relationships with more people across longer distances. While moving to another city or country we do not feel isolation so much anymore. It allows us to mentain or ralationships longer and stronger. At the same time such an option give people a possibility to avoid face-to-face communication with people phisically close to them. As for me it gives only one disadvantage - it is getting harder to load some parts of our brain which are evolutionary oriented to face-to-face interraction.I can conclude that social media interraction gave us some new possibilities and cut off some of the old ones. At the same time modern technologies blur boundaries between a real conversation and internet communication. Now we can perfectly see and hear each-other and even support financially. There are also some devises wich allow you to feel even more - like touches or heartrythm of each other. I think that new social media tools and some next directions of these tools will satisfy our face-to-face communication needs more and more over time.
llm: To my mind, the disadvantages outweigh the advantages. Social media have revolutionized the way people interact with each other. Aside from staying in touch with friends and family living far away, it has opened up a way for people to express themselves and for people with similar views to meet each other. On the other hand, some disadvantages of social media have also emerged. And that is, there are also some misinformation, cyberbullying and social comparison that have an adverse effect on the health of users. People who spend more time with their mobile phone screens than with people are also deprived of this skill. With this in mind, people should try to balance their life between the virtual and the real. It is also necessary for them to maintain their social and emotional well-being. To sum up, I think that social media are good, but that the disadvantages of replacing face-to-face interaction outweigh the advantages.

question: The world health organization recommends that people should eat five or more portion of fruit and vegetables per day. The bar chart shows the percentage of males and females in the UK by age group in 2006.You should write at least 150 words.
human: This bar chart depicts the percentage between male and female to eat five or above portion of fruit and vegetables per day in the UK. It is clear from the graph that the female is higher than male of percentage.According to what is shown, gradually increased from 19 to 34 ages same that from 35 to 54 ages. Between 55 and 64 ages is siginficant increased about between 19 and 24 ages, After that gradually decreased between 65 and 74. Although, Supposed to 25 and 34 ages, They the more consum but between 55 and 64 ages they is consum the highest. Also, The 75 age is the same percentage, unlike the all under 75 ages.To sum up, we could say that, the all ages is not equal between male and female in same percentage ages, except 75 age, They slight by 25 per cent between unisex. On other hand, Female and male is equal consume in 75 age.
llm: This essay will discuss the implications of the world health organization’s recommendations, in the light of the information given in the bar chart. The world health organization recommends that five or more portions of fruit and vegetables should be consumed by people in order to lead a healthy life. According to the bar chart, there is a notable variation in the percentage of males and females who meet this recommendation in different age groups. For example, the percentages of females between 50 and 64 and 65 and over are higher than those of the younger females and the males of the same age. The information shows that the older people are more likely to follow a healthy diet, which may be due to an increased awareness of health problems or because of health conditions that require them to have a healthy diet. On the other hand, the younger people are less likely to be aware of the health benefits of a diet rich in fruits and vegetables, and they may also be hindered by the cost, availability and personal preference, to meet the recommended daily intake. In the end, the bar chart reveals that the age and gender differences in the consumption of fruits and vegetables in the UK are important. Consequently, in order to prevent further health problems and encourage a healthy diet, health education must be promoted among the younger people.

question: The world is experiencing a dramatic increase in population, which is causing problems not only for poor, undeveloped countries, but also for industrialized and developed nations. Describe some of the problems that overpopulation causes, and suggest at least one possible solution.
human: You should write at least 250 words.You should spend about 40 minutes on this task.Nowadays, the population dramatically in most countries around the world. This is true for the developed and developing nations. Overpopulation a different number of problems. However, the government can these problems in many .There are several problems that the raising number of people in undeveloped countries causes. Firstly, it is very difficult to provide enough food for all people. Secondly, the government limits the number of children per family in school. In addition, in poorest countries usually have , and when the population increases, the number of . Finally, when too many people live on the land, the environment suffers.There are different problems that overpopulation causes in rich nations. Firstly, it is very difficult for governments to provide helpful public services in overcrowded cities. Moreover, there is generally a higher level of crimes being committed, such as drugs abuse, murders, thefts, . often cause by the high rates of unemployment.However, overpopulation problems in nations have two main which they are by governments. Firstly, the government must educate people about limiting the size of the family. For example, in China they have a policy called “one child policy” which limits the size of the family to one or two children, and this is beginning to have an effect on the world’s most crowded nation.To sum up, if the impulsive population increase continues, many more people will die of hunger in the poor countries. Also, in rich nations, the life in the cities will become more and more difficult.
llm: One of the main problems caused by overpopulation is a strain on natural resources. The world population is growing at an unprecedented rate, causing many problems for both rich and poor countries. Overcrowded cities also put a strain on services, leading to poor living conditions. Increasing numbers of people put a strain on the natural resources of food, water and energy, and these are increasingly being depleted. This is followed by a shortage of food and water, and increased greenhouse gas emissions, which hasten climate change. In addition, as a result of overpopulation, the loss of species is increasing as natural habitats are destroyed to accommodate the growing population. One possible solution to this is to implement effective family planning and education programmes. This would reduce the need for social services in developed countries, and increase prosperity in poor countries. In addition, investing in sustainable agriculture, alternative energy and urban planning can help to meet the needs of the growing population and minimize damage to the environment. By educating women and girls and providing them with access to family planning and reproductive health care, governments and international organizations could help people make informed choices about the size of their families, which would help to slow down population growth and reduce poverty. In order to tackle the problem of overpopulation, governments, international organizations and individuals need to work together to promote sustainable development, and ensure a viable future for everyone.
